page.title: 01N. Lopham Area, Introduction
page.content:
The rectangle surrounding N. Lopham is almost all agricultural land. Our landscape is flat with lots of open sky. We can see many trees, but they are getting fewer. Many hedgerows have been taken out by farmers. Most of the land is arable. The crops mostly grown are: sugar beet, rape, wheat, potatoes, barley. There are also several small 'battery' egg producing factories and pig units.
The village was once famous for growing and working flax and hemp. Today nothing is left except a few weavers' cottages and the village pond (Letchmere), where flax and hemp were once soaked to loosen the fibres. N. Lopham also has a war memorial, a church and a Methodist chapel. The school is a Voluntary Aided Church of England Primary.
